        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "I'm up for The Crooked Billet, but what do you guys think?
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "I'm up for The Crooked Billet, but what do you guys think?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
      Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but I'm open to other suggestions too.
      Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? I always have a good time there.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet's the place to be for the game.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about this pub thing, guys. I'm feeling pretty tired.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game here at the park?"
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "I'm up for The Crooked Billet, but what do you guys think?

      • Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.

          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action B.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action B.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:## Analyzing Jack Taylor's Actions:
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:## Analyzing Jack Taylor's Actions:

          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action B.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game here at the park?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where his friends are lounging and discussing where to watch the Serbia-Andorra game. They are considering watching it at The Crooked Billet.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.

Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:## Analyzing Jack Taylor's Actions:

          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action B.

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "I'm up for The Crooked Billet, but what do you guys think?

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where his friends are lounging and discussing where to watch the Serbia-Andorra game. They are considering watching it at The Crooked Billet.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "I'm up for The Crooked Billet, but maybe we could check out some other places too? I'm open to suggestions.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "I'm up for The Crooked Billet, but maybe we could check out some other places too? I'm open to suggestions.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
      Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but I'm open to other suggestions too.
      Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? I always have a good time there.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet's the place to be for the game.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about this pub thing, guys. I'm feeling pretty tired.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game here at the park?"
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
      Jack Taylor -- "I'm up for The Crooked Billet, but what do you guys think?


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "I'm up for The Crooked Billet, but maybe we could check out some other places too? I'm open to suggestions.

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest watching the game at the park, emphasizing the pleasant weather and the opportunity to enjoy the outdoors together; B: Alice Lewis could express her willingness to go to The Crooked Billet, but also suggest compromising on a different pub if others have strong preferences; C: Alice Lewis could ask her friends what they think about watching the game at the park, highlighting the relaxed atmosphere and the chance to have a picnic.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.

          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:B: Alice Lewis could express her willingness to go to The Crooked Billet, but also suggest compromising on a different pub if others have strong preferences.

        • Alice Lewis -- "I'm up for The Crooked Billet, but maybe we could check out some other places too? I'm open to suggestions.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park where her friends are lounging and discussing where to watch the Serbia vs. Andorra game. They are considering watching it at The Crooked Billet pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest watching the game at the park, emphasizing the pleasant weather and the opportunity to enjoy the outdoors together; B: Alice Lewis could express her willingness to go to The Crooked Billet, but also suggest compromising on a different pub if others have strong preferences; C: Alice Lewis could ask her friends what they think about watching the game at the park, highlighting the relaxed atmosphere and the chance to have a picnic.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Alice Lewis suggests watching the game at the park, emphasizing the pleasant weather and the opportunity to enjoy the outdoors together.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:B: Alice Lewis could express her willingness to go to The Crooked Billet, but also suggest compromising on a different pub if others have strong preferences.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "I'm up for The Crooked Billet, but maybe we could check out some other places too? I'm open to suggestions.

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest watching the game at the park, emphasizing the pleasant weather and the opportunity to enjoy the outdoors together; B: Alice Lewis could express her willingness to go to The Crooked Billet, but also suggest compromising on a different pub if others have strong preferences; C: Alice Lewis could ask her friends what they think about watching the game at the park, highlighting the relaxed atmosphere and the chance to have a picnic.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park where her friends are lounging and discussing where to watch the Serbia vs. Andorra game. They are considering watching it at The Crooked Billet pub.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest watching the game at the park, emphasizing the pleasant weather and the opportunity to enjoy the outdoors together; B: Alice Lewis could express her willingness to go to The Crooked Billet, but also suggest compromising on a different pub if others have strong preferences; C: Alice Lewis could ask her friends what they think about watching the game at the park, highlighting the relaxed atmosphere and the chance to have a picnic.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise:

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White decided to go to a pub to watch a game.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game here at the park?"
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could ask his friends if they want to watch the game at Victoria Park; B: Alexander White could suggest ordering food and drinks to enjoy at the park; C: Alexander White could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Alexander White could ask his friends if they want to watch the game at Victoria Park.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:Action A.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (b)

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could ask his friends if they want to watch the game at Victoria Park; B: Alexander White could suggest ordering food and drinks to enjoy at the park; C: Alexander White could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

  • William Jones

      Action attempt
    • The Crooked Billet

        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with friends, both at pubs and in the park; he seems to be a fan of soccer and often watches games with his friends.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Crooked Billet, or he could try to convince his friends to go somewhere else.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:## Analyzing Jack Taylor's Actions:

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Answer: Jack Taylor decided to go to a pub to watch a game.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:## Analyzing Jack Taylor's Actions:

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action B.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (a)

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 3/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

        • The Crooked Billet

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who craves camaraderie but struggles to connect with others on a deeper level.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling tired and lonely but plans to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation but feels tired and lonely.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to find a way to connect with his friends on a deeper level or seek solace in familiar surroundings.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Crooked Billet

          State

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to engage more with his friends and find a way to connect with them on a deeper level.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? I always have a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet's the place to be for the game.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely seek solace in familiar surroundings and routine.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jacob Walker just arrived.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 4/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest a specific pub that she thinks everyone would enjoy, emphasizing the positive aspects of that location; B: Alice Lewis could ask her friends for their opinions on different pub options, expressing her willingness to be flexible and go with the group's preference; C: Alice Lewis could propose a compromise, suggesting a new pub that she hasn't been to before but thinks might be a good fit for the group.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Alice Lewis suggests a specific pub that she thinks everyone would enjoy, emphasizing the positive aspects of that location.
          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:B: Alice Lewis could ask her friends for their opinions on different pub options, expressing her willingness to be flexible and go with the group's preference.

          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          ['[16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub. ', '[16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] ']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest a specific pub that she thinks everyone would enjoy, emphasizing the positive aspects of that location; B: Alice Lewis could ask her friends for their opinions on different pub options, expressing her willingness to be flexible and go with the group's preference; C: Alice Lewis could propose a compromise, suggesting a new pub that she hasn't been to before but thinks might be a good fit for the group.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Alice Lewis suggests a specific pub that she thinks everyone would enjoy, emphasizing the positive aspects of that location.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:B: Alice Lewis could ask her friends for their opinions on different pub options, expressing her willingness to be flexible and go with the group's preference.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest a specific pub that she thinks everyone would enjoy, emphasizing the positive aspects of that location; B: Alice Lewis could ask her friends for their opinions on different pub options, expressing her willingness to be flexible and go with the group's preference; C: Alice Lewis could propose a compromise, suggesting a new pub that she hasn't been to before but thinks might be a good fit for the group.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest a specific pub that she thinks everyone would enjoy, emphasizing the positive aspects of that location; B: Alice Lewis could ask her friends for their opinions on different pub options, expressing her willingness to be flexible and go with the group's preference; C: Alice Lewis could propose a compromise, suggesting a new pub that she hasn't been to before but thinks might be a good fit for the group.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 5/5
      Payoffs

William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
      Alice Lewis observed: William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
      Alexander White observed: William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. 2015-05-14 10:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          William Jones's Summary of recent observations:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones is spending time with friends in Victoria Park and they are planning to watch the Andorra-Portugal football game at a pub later.
          William Jones's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: William Jones is currently in Victoria Park with friends and plans to watch the Andorra-Portugal football game at a pub later.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones is currently in Victoria Park with friends and plans to watch the Andorra-Portugal football game at a pub later.

        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, decided to skip school and spend the day at the lake. William, eager to be included, had packed a lunch and was ready to go when they arrived, already laughing and joking without him. They told him they'd decided to go without him because he was "too slow" and "always complaining". He watched them leave, his face burning with shame and resentment.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Role playing instructions

        • Role playing instructions

        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.

      • Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.

        • Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:A: Alice Lewis could suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends of the positive experiences they've had there before.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she was convinced her best friend, Jack Taylor, stole the lead role in the school play from her. She practiced her lines obsessively, believing she was the more talented actress, and harbored a grudge against Jack for years to come, convinced he had used his charm to manipulate the drama teacher.
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 20, she spent her first night at The Clapton Hart with her friends, Jack, Alex, William, and Jacob. Despite the warm atmosphere and friendly staff, Alice found herself fixated on a group of people laughing at a nearby table, convinced they were mocking her and her friends. This paranoia colored the entire evening, turning what should have been a fun outing into a night of simmering resentment.
