          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends of the positive experiences they've had there before.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:**Action A: Alice Lewis suggests The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are enjoying the sunshine and snacks. Later tonight, the group plans to watch the Andorra-Portugal game at a pub, possibly The Crooked Billet.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends of the positive experiences they've had there before.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents.           Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:**Action A: Alice Lewis suggests The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:A: Alice Lewis could suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends of the positive experiences they've had there before.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she was convinced her best friend, Jack Taylor, stole the lead role in the school play from her. She practiced her lines obsessively, believing she was the more talented actress, and harbored a grudge against Jack for years to come, convinced he had used his charm to manipulate the drama teacher.
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 20, she spent her first night at The Clapton Hart with her friends, Jack, Alex, William, and Jacob. Despite the warm atmosphere and friendly staff, Alice found herself fixated on a group of people laughing at a nearby table, convinced they were mocking her and her friends. This paranoia colored the entire evening, turning what should have been a fun outing into a night of simmering resentment.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he orchestrated a daring prank on the school principal, replacing the morning announcements with a recording of his own fiery speech about the injustices of homework. The thrill of orchestrating the chaos, of seeing the entire school thrown into confusion, left him exhilarated. It was a taste of the power he craved, the ability to disrupt the mundane and ignite a spark of excitement.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, decided to celebrate the end of exams with a night out at The Clapton Hart. The pub's lively atmosphere and the promise of its innovative cuisine fueled their excitement. Alexander, fueled by pints of ale and the camaraderie of his friends, launched into a passionate debate about the merits of various political ideologies, his voice rising above the din of the pub as he argued with fervor and conviction.

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest going to The Clapton Hart, as it's his favorite pub and he knows his friends enjoy it too. B: Alexander White could ask his friends what they think and try to find a solution that works for everyone. C: Alexander White could express his enthusiasm for watching the game with his friends, regardless of the location.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alexander White to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, decided to celebrate the end of exams with a night out at The Clapton Hart. The pub's lively atmosphere and the promise of its innovative cuisine fueled their excitement. Alexander, fueled by pints of ale and the camaraderie of his friends, launched into a passionate debate about the merits of various political ideologies, his voice rising above the din of the pub as he argued with fervor and conviction.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:Serves innovative and globally-inspired cuisine.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.

Alexander White just arrived.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alexander White is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest going to The Clapton Hart, as it's his favorite pub and he knows his friends enjoy it too. B: Alexander White could ask his friends what they think and try to find a solution that works for everyone. C: Alexander White could express his enthusiasm for watching the game with his friends, regardless of the location.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:**Action A: Alexander White suggests going to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:Action B.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest going to The Clapton Hart, as it's his favorite pub and he knows his friends enjoy it too. B: Alexander White could ask his friends what they think and try to find a solution that works for everyone. C: Alexander White could express his enthusiasm for watching the game with his friends, regardless of the location.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
      Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game later that evening.

Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of both violence and a desire for camaraderie.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is relaxing with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game later that evening.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely advocate for his preferred pub, The Crooked Billet, but would ultimately be open to going wherever the group decides.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.

          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00]

The taunts and shoves quickly escalated, and Jacob, consumed by a white-hot rage, lashed out, landing a punch that sent one boy sprawling. The ensuing fight, though brief, left Jacob shaken but strangely exhilarated, a dangerous taste of power lingering on his tongue.

      • Role playing instructions

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but I'm open to other suggestions too.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but I'm open to other suggestions too.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
      Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but I'm open to other suggestions too.

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:## Analyzing Jack Taylor's Actions:

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are lounging and discussing where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later that night.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:## Analyzing Jack Taylor's Actions:


          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action B.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but I'm open to other suggestions too.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
      Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but I'm open to other suggestions too.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of violence and a desire for camaraderie.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely advocate for his preferred pub, The Crooked Billet, but would ultimately be open to going wherever the group decides.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart.           Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at a market and later plans to watch a soccer game with them.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, but feeling somewhat isolated despite being with friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to engage more with his friends and find a way to connect with them on a deeper level.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
      Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but I'm open to other suggestions too.
      Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

        Question_3
      • Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Key

        • Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer
          State

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.

          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:## Analyzing Jack Taylor's Actions:

          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action B.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are enjoying coffee and pastries; later that night, they plan to watch the Ireland-Russia game at The Crooked Billet pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:## Analyzing Jack Taylor's Actions:


          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action B.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action B.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are enjoying coffee and pastries; later that night, they plan to watch the Ireland-Russia game at The Crooked Billet pub.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a compromise, like finding a pub that is agreeable to everyone; B: Jack Taylor could express his preference for The Crooked Billet but be open to hearing everyone else's opinions and be willing to go with the majority decision; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help make a reservation or call ahead to ensure they have enough space at whichever pub they choose.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
      Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but I'm open to other suggestions too.
      Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest going to The Crooked Billet, as it seems to be a popular choice among his friends. B: Alexander White could express his enthusiasm for watching the game with his friends, regardless of the location. C: Alexander White could ask his friends for their opinions and try to facilitate a consensus.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest going to The Clapton Hart, as it's his favorite pub and he knows his friends enjoy it too. B: Alexander White could ask his friends what they think and try to find a solution that works for everyone. C: Alexander White could express his enthusiasm for watching the game with his friends, regardless of the location.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

B: Alexander White could reiterate his preference for The Clapton Hart, but emphasize his willingness to go wherever the group decides. C: Alexander White could ask his friends for their opinions and try to facilitate a consensus.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest going to The Crooked Billet, as it seems to be a popular choice among his friends. B: Alexander White could express his enthusiasm for watching the game with his friends, regardless of the location. C: Alexander White could ask his friends for their opinions and try to facilitate a consensus.

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest going to The Crooked Billet, as it seems to be a popular choice among his friends. B: Alexander White could express his enthusiasm for watching the game with his friends, regardless of the location. C: Alexander White could ask his friends for their opinions and try to facilitate a consensus.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White just arrived at a market where his friends are gathered, and they are discussing where to watch the Ireland vs. Russia game later that night.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest going to The Crooked Billet, as it seems to be a popular choice among his friends. B: Alexander White could express his enthusiasm for watching the game with his friends, regardless of the location. C: Alexander White could ask his friends for their opinions and try to facilitate a consensus.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? I always have a good time there.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? I always have a good time there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, you know what would be great? Catching the Andorra game at The Crooked Billet tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Clapton Hart for the game? They always have such a great atmosphere, and the staff are so friendly.
      Alexander White -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? They usually have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game, guys. It's practically a tradition.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but I'm open to other suggestions too.
      Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? I always have a good time there.

          Value

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends of the positive experiences they've had there before; B: Alice Lewis could ask her friends what they think about The Clapton Hart, expressing her own preference for it but being open to other suggestions; C: Alice Lewis could compromise and suggest trying a new pub that everyone agrees on, emphasizing the importance of spending time together as a group.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Alice Lewis suggests The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game.
          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:B: Alice Lewis could ask her friends what they think about The Clapton Hart, expressing her own preference for it but being open to other suggestions.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Answer: Alice Lewis was observed at a market with friends and later, the group discussed where to watch a soccer game between Ireland and Russia.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? I always have a good time there.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "You guys know, there's only one place worth watching the game tonight. The Crooked Billet. It's got the best atmosphere, the best beer, and the best... well, everything really.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me, but what do you guys think?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis was observed at a market with friends and later, the group discussed where to watch a soccer game between Ireland and Russia.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A: Alice Lewis could suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends of the positive experiences they've had there before; B: Alice Lewis could ask her friends what they think about The Clapton Hart, expressing her own preference for it but being open to other suggestions; C: Alice Lewis could compromise and suggest trying a new pub that everyone agrees on, emphasizing the importance of spending time together as a group.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Alice Lewis suggests The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:B: Alice Lewis could ask her friends what they think about The Clapton Hart, expressing her own preference for it but being open to other suggestions.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "What do you guys think about The Clapton Hart? I always have a good time there.
